channel.title: California
channel.description: California news and features from the Los Angeles Times.

item.title: Firefighters 'running on fumes' as Bay Area blazes spread, with more lightning looming
item.dc:creator: Susanne Rust, Joseph Serna, Rong-Gong Lin II, Anita Chabria
item.description: Santa Cruz fire agencies say they are not getting enough help from the state, which admits it is struggling with too many fires and not enough resources.
item.content:encoded: Santa Cruz fire agencies say they are not getting enough help from the state, which admits it is struggling with too many fires and not enough resources.

item.title: She ripped Trump for her dad's COVID-19 death. She hopes her fame will drive change
item.dc:creator: Susanne Rust
item.description: Kristin Urquiza delivered a powerful indictment of Trump's handling of the coronavirus crisis, blaming the president for her father's death.
item.content:encoded: Kristin Urquiza delivered a powerful indictment of Trump's handling of the coronavirus crisis, blaming the president for her father's death.

media:content.media:description: In this image from video, Kristin Urquiza of San Francisco, speaks during the first night of the Democratic National Convention on Monday, Aug. 17, 2020. (Democratic National Convention via AP)

item.title: LAPD fires projectiles as protesters clash at Trump rally
item.dc:creator: Leila Miller
item.description: The Los Angeles Police Department fired projectiles as two groups of protesters clashed in Tujunga Friday afternoon, authorities said.
item.content:encoded: The Los Angeles Police Department fired projectiles as two groups of protesters clashed in Tujunga Friday afternoon, authorities said.

item.title: Earthquake: 2.5 shakes Huntington Beach
item.dc:creator: Quakebot
item.description: A magnitude 2.5 earthquake was reported Friday evening at 11:19 p.m. Pacific time in Huntington Beach, according to the U.S. Geological Survey.
item.content:encoded: A magnitude 2.5 earthquake was reported Friday evening at 11:19 p.m. Pacific time in Huntington Beach, according to the U.S. Geological Survey.

item.title: LAPD resumes enforcement to clear tents in Venice Beach
item.dc:creator: Gale Holland, Kevin Rector
item.description: Los Angeles police will resume enforcing a ban on homeless people pitching tents and lean-tos around the Venice boardwalk
item.content:encoded: Los Angeles police will resume enforcing a ban on homeless people pitching tents and lean-tos around the Venice boardwalk

media:content.media:description: Marcus Steinlechner, 22, drags his bedding between a garbage truck and a city sanitation truck during a sweep of homeless encampments on the boardwalk at Venice Beach on June 26.

item.title: Animal rescue sues to reopen L.A. shelters closed during pandemic
item.dc:creator: Emily Alpert Reyes
item.description: A San Fernando Valley animal rescue is suing Los Angeles Animal Services, arguing that the city must reopen two of its animal shelters that have been shuttered since April.
item.content:encoded: A San Fernando Valley animal rescue is suing Los Angeles Animal Services, arguing that the city must reopen two of its animal shelters that have been shuttered since April.

media:content.media:description: A German shepherd mix dog peers from his cage at the Chesterfield Square shelter in South Los Angeles.
media:content.media:credit: Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times

item.title: 'You can still taste the smoke': As fire rages near UC Santa Cruz, thousands are forced to evacuate
item.dc:creator: Susanne Rust, Joseph Serna
item.description: The UC Santa Cruz campus and nearby towns have been under evacuation orders due to wildfires in the region.
item.content:encoded: The UC Santa Cruz campus and nearby towns have been under evacuation orders due to wildfires in the region.

media:content.media:description: SANTA CRUZ, CA - AUGUST 21: People sit on an empty beach as smoke from the fires and a marine layer roll in slightly obscuring the view of the Santa Cruz Wharf near the Santa Cruz Beach Boardwalk during the CZU August Lightning Complex Fires on Friday, Aug. 21, 2020 in Santa Cruz, CA. The University of California at Santa Cruz campus and nearby towns have been under evacuation orders due to fires in the region. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Some Orange County schools to reopen as COVID-19 cases drop. What about L.A.?
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby
item.description: The Orange County Health Care Agency said Thursday that the California Department of Public Health has approved the reopening for in-person learning at at least 24 private elementary schools and one public K-6 school.
item.content:encoded: The Orange County Health Care Agency said Thursday that the California Department of Public Health has approved the reopening for in-person learning at at least 24 private elementary schools and one public K-6 school.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA -AUGUST 19, 2020: Gladys Alvarez, a 5th grade teacher at Manchester Ave. Elementary School in South Los Angeles, talks to her students during ameet and greet on Wednesday afternoon. Alvarez was sitting inside her empty classroom while conducting the virtual zoom class. (Mel Melcon / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Active shooter call in San Luis Obispo County ends with deputies killing suspect
item.dc:creator: Faith E. Pinho
item.description: Witnesses told sheriff's officials that a man was firing a handgun indiscriminately outside a Vons shopping center.
item.content:encoded: Witnesses told sheriff's officials that a man was firing a handgun indiscriminately outside a Vons shopping center.

item.title: Do you work for the U.S. Postal Service? Tell us what you're seeing
item.dc:creator: Laura J. Nelson, Maya Lau
item.description: The COVID-19 pandemic and cutbacks at USPS have created chaos in the mail system. Do you work for the Postal Service? We want to hear from you.
item.content:encoded: The COVID-19 pandemic and cutbacks at USPS have created chaos in the mail system. Do you work for the Postal Service? We want to hear from you.

media:content.media:description: One individual was found to have tens of thousands of pieces of mail in her possession, the U.S. attorney's office said.

item.title: Britney Spears' dad's latest move doesn't satisfy her conservatorship demands
item.dc:creator: Nardine Saad
item.description: After Britney Spears moved to oust her father as her sole conservator, Jamie Spears agreed to bring back a co-conservator to manage her person and estate.
item.content:encoded: After Britney Spears moved to oust her father as her sole conservator, Jamie Spears agreed to bring back a co-conservator to manage her person and estate.

media:content.media:description: Britney Spears in 2013 at Planet Hollywood Resort & Casino in Las Vegas.

item.title: UCLA sharply scales back reopening plans under strict county rules
item.dc:creator: Teresa Watanabe
item.description: UCLA will further scale back fall reopening plans, sharply limiting on-campus housing and in-person classes, to comply with strict L.A. County public health rules on what local colleges and universities must do to protect against the coronavirus.
item.content:encoded: UCLA will further scale back fall reopening plans, sharply limiting on-campus housing and in-person classes, to comply with strict L.A. County public health rules on what local colleges and universities must do to protect against the coronavirus.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - AUGUST 05, 2020 - - A lone jogger runs past Royce Hall on a nearly empty UCLA campus in Los Angeles on August 13, 2020. The empty campus is a preview of what the Fall semester will look like during the coronavirus pandemic. Most classes, much like the summer classes, will be held online at the university. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California's job growth slowed dramatically in July: 'A listlessness set in'
item.dc:creator: Margot Roosevelt
item.description: California's job growth decelerates last month, lagging the overall U.S., amid rising COVID-19 infections and shuttered businesses.
item.content:encoded: California's job growth decelerates last month, lagging the overall U.S., amid rising COVID-19 infections and shuttered businesses.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - AUG. 6, 2020. A waman walks past a shuttered restaurant in Los Angeles on Thursday, Aug. 6, 2020. Weeks after the social unrest following Floyd's death, some of the looted and vadalized stores downtown remain boarded up. Many downtown stores and eateries also remain shuttered or restricted because of coronavirus. Leases and rents are spiraling downward, and large numbers of homeless people live on the streets. (Luis Sinco/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Building owners connected to massive downtown L.A. explosion face 300 criminal charges
item.dc:creator: Richard Winton, James Queally
item.description: The L.A. city attorney has filed more than 300 charges against the owners of four downtown buildings after a May 16 explosion burned 11 firefighters.
item.content:encoded: The L.A. city attorney has filed more than 300 charges against the owners of four downtown buildings after a May 16 explosion burned 11 firefighters.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA -- MAY 16: Firefighters first received a call about 6:30 p.m. about a structure fire in the 300 block of Boyd Street south of Little Tokyo, said Erik Scott, a spokesman for the Los Angeles Fire Department, in downtown on Saturday, May 16, 2020, in Los Angeles, CA. The fire left 11 firefighters injured, authorities said. (Gary Coronado / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Admissions scandal: Lori Loughlin sentenced to 2 months in prison; Giannulli gets 5 months
item.dc:creator: Matthew Ormseth
item.description: For fixing their daughters' admission to USC, Lori Loughlin and J. Mossimo Giannulli were sentenced to two months and five months, respectively, in prison.
item.content:encoded: For fixing their daughters' admission to USC, Lori Loughlin and J. Mossimo Giannulli were sentenced to two months and five months, respectively, in prison.

item.title: Have L.A.'s homeless people dodged a COVID-19 catastrophe?
item.dc:creator: Gale Holland
item.description: One reason L.A.'s homeless people have avoided a COVID disaster could be that they live outside
item.content:encoded: One reason L.A.'s homeless people have avoided a COVID disaster could be that they live outside

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - AUG. 11, 2020. Homeless encampments line the sidewalk along Fith Street in Los Angeles on Tuesday, Aug. 11, 2020. Many downtown stores and eateries remain shuttered or restricted because of coronavirus. Leases and rents are spiraling downward, and large numbers of homeless people live on the streets. (Luis Sinco/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Bay Area fires rank in the top 5 in California history
item.dc:creator: Joseph Serna, Susanne Rust, Anita Chabria, Rong-Gong Lin II
item.description: Fires in Northern and Central California have killed at least five people, destroyed 629 structures and scorched more than 1,400 square miles.
item.content:encoded: Fires in Northern and Central California have killed at least five people, destroyed 629 structures and scorched more than 1,400 square miles.

media:content.media:description: Thomas Henney, right, and Charles Chavira watch a plume spread over Healdsburg, Calif., as the LNU Lightning Complex fires burn, Thursday, Aug. 20, 2020. Fire crews across the region scrambled to contain dozens of wildfires sparked by lightning strikes. (AP Photo/Noah Berger)

item.title: It's dÃ©jÃ vu in the Bay Area as fires again force evacuations and cloud the skies
item.dc:creator: Anita Chabria, Joe Mozingo, Joseph Serna
item.description: A cluster of wildfires has again prompted evacuations in Sonoma County and other parts of the North Bay.
item.content:encoded: A cluster of wildfires has again prompted evacuations in Sonoma County and other parts of the North Bay.

media:content.media:description: FELTON, CA - AUGUST 20: Firefighters from First Strike Engine 1 out of Eugene, Oregon inspect a fire burning near a structure along Pine Flat road during the CZU August Lightning Complex Fires on Thursday, Aug. 20, 2020 in Felton, CA. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Golden State Killer given life in prison for rapes, murders that terrorized a generation
item.dc:creator: Paige St. John, Luke Money
item.description: Joseph James DeAngelo Jr., a former cop who murdered 13 people and raped more than 50 women and girls, was sentenced to life in prison.
item.content:encoded: Joseph James DeAngelo Jr., a former cop who murdered 13 people and raped more than 50 women and girls, was sentenced to life in prison.

media:content.media:description: Joseph James DeAngelo Jr. at his sentencing held at CSU Sacramento on Friday, Aug. 21, 2020, in Sacramento, Calif. DeAngelo Jr., 74, was sentenced to 11 life sentences in prison without the possibility of parole, one life sentence with the possibility of parole and an additional eight year sentence under a plea agreement that allowed him to avoid the death sentence. In June, DeAngelo Jr. admitted being the infamous Golden State Killer. The former police officer in California eluded capture for four decades. He admitted killing 13 people and raping nearly 50 people in the 1970s and 1980s. The sentencing was held at the University Union, a large enough space so that people could maintain physical distance, amid the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: The surprising story of the salesman who became L.A.'s first known COVID-19 patient
item.dc:creator: Harriet Ryan, Paige St. John, Xinlu Liang
item.description: The first confirmed case of COVID-19 in Los Angeles was a man from Wuhan, China, who was hospitalized in a secret ward in January and remained the sole patient diagnosed with the virus here for five weeks.
item.content:encoded: The first confirmed case of COVID-19 in Los Angeles was a man from Wuhan, China, who was hospitalized in a secret ward in January and remained the sole patient diagnosed with the virus here for five weeks.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MAY 22: Hainan Airlines flight crew in full biohazard suit at Tom Bradley Terminal. Due to global pandemic and upcoming Memorial Day Weekend travelers are strongly advised to follow mask and social distancing recommendations at Los Angeles International Airport. Los Angeles Airport LAX on Friday, May 22, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: 'It's a frustrating period.' Yet LAUSD teachers muster smiles on the first day of school

item.title: La Luz Del Mundo leader held on all counts of rape, child pornography and sex trafficking
item.dc:creator: Matthew Ormseth
item.description: One after the other, the agents settled into the witness box and related what teenaged girls and young women had told them: Naason Joaquin Garcia, the leader of La Luz Del Mundo, an international church headquartered in Mexico, had raped them.
item.content:encoded: One after the other, the agents settled into the witness box and related what teenaged girls and young women had told them: Naason Joaquin Garcia, the leader of La Luz Del Mundo, an international church headquartered in Mexico, had raped them.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA -AUGUST05: Naason Joaquin Garcia, the leader of the Guadalajara-based La Luz del Mundo church, at his bail hearing held at Clara Shortridge Foltz Criminal Justice Center on Wednesday, Aug. 5, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Irfan Khan/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Plan to strengthen California's police use of force rules blocked in Sacramento
item.dc:creator: Melody Gutierrez
item.description: A bill to add tough penalties for police officers who do not intervene when witnessing a fellow officer use excessive force was sidelined in the California Legislature on Thursday. Assembly Bill 1022 by Assemblyman Chris Holden (D-Pasadena) would have made an officer an accessory to a crime if they were capable of stopping an incident of excessive force by another officer and failed to do so.
item.content:encoded: A bill to add tough penalties for police officers who do not intervene when witnessing a fellow officer use excessive force was sidelined in the California Legislature on Thursday. Assembly Bill 1022 by Assemblyman Chris Holden (D-Pasadena) would have made an officer an accessory to a crime if they were capable of stopping an incident of excessive force by another officer and failed to do so.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA -- MAY 30: Protestors are arrested by Los Angeles police in front of City Hall as they demonstrate in downtown on Saturday, May 30, 2020, in Los Angeles, CA. The protestors demonstrated in response to the death of George Floyd in Minnesota. More than 500 arrests were made after looting and vandalism sweep downtown L.A. (Gary Coronado / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Compton Executioners deputy gang lied about guns and hosted inking parties, deputy says
item.dc:creator: Alene Tchekmedyian
item.description: 'Ghost guns,' inking parties and a decades-long struggle to crack down on cliques within the Sheriff's Department
item.content:encoded: 'Ghost guns,' inking parties and a decades-long struggle to crack down on cliques within the Sheriff's Department

media:content.media:description: Los Angeles County Sheriff's Deputy Samuel Aldama admitted as part of a lawsuit this year that he has a skull tattoo on his calf associated with the Compton Station, where he worked. The photo of his tattoo emerged in the lawsuit. The department has a long history with deputy tattoos that officials say represent cliques that promote overly aggressive policing. NOTE: The photo is an exhibit to a motion filed in court by plaintiff Andrew Taylor.

item.title: Wildfire damages much of Big Basin Redwoods State Park. Fate of big trees unknown

item.description: California's oldest state park has suffered extensive damage from the C.Z.U. August Lightning Complex fires.
item.content:encoded: California's oldest state park has suffered extensive damage from the C.Z.U. August Lightning Complex fires.

item.title: Kamala Harris' husband, Doug Emhoff, could also make history

item.description: Friends say the 55-year-old entertainment lawyer, who attended college and law school in Southern California and lives in L.A.'s Brentwood, would "make an impact" should Biden and Harris win in November.

item.title: No deal yet in Sacramento to help struggling California renters
item.dc:creator: Patrick McGreevy
item.description: Facing extraordinary circumstances because of the COVID-19 pandemic and a looming deadline for legislative action, California lawmakers on Thursday reduced the number of bills moving forward that deal with the state's affordable housing crisis.
item.content:encoded: Facing extraordinary circumstances because of the COVID-19 pandemic and a looming deadline for legislative action, California lawmakers on Thursday reduced the number of bills moving forward that deal with the state's affordable housing crisis.

media:content.media:description: EL MONTE, CA - MARCH 29: Ian Jameson (left) of El Monte organized hold a sign along with other tenant rights activists assembled at the El Monte City Hall to demand that the El Monte City Council pass an eviction moratorium barring all evictions during the coronavirus pandemic on Sunday, March 29, 2020 in El Monte, CA. (Jason Armond / Los Angeles Times)

item.content:encoded: Two Los Angeles County sheriff's captains are on administrative leave following allegations of sexual misconduct, according to officials and public safety sources.

item.content:encoded: The California Independent System Operator, which runs the electric grid for most of the state, said further power outages aren't anticipated.

media:content.media:description: From left, Sebastian Grand, 11, Leo Grand, 13, and Constantin Condraschi, 12, of Orange County laugh outside A Slice of New York Pizza in Seal Beach. The trio has been friends since preschool and had pizza after a day together at the beach.

item.title: Two arrested in hate crime, robbery of transgender women in Hollywood
item.dc:creator: James Queally
item.description: Two people have been arrested in connection with the robbery and beating of three transgender women in Hollywood, the LAPD announced.
item.content:encoded: Two people have been arrested in connection with the robbery and beating of three transgender women in Hollywood, the LAPD announced.

media:content.media:description: Place: Hollywood Boulevard Last visited: Fall 2008 My perspective: Most tourists are expecting to see all of the glitz of Hollywood and the sidewalks lined with movie stars. They don't realize that what has been sold to them in the movies and on television is an illusion until they actually get there. All they get to see is a sidewalk, a few interesting old movie theaters and a bunch of shops. Suggested alternative: Getty Museum, Walt Disney Concert Hall --Chris Nunez, Los Angeles

item.title: 'Like Armageddon': Rotting food, dead animals and chaos at postal facilities amid cutbacks
item.dc:creator: Laura J. Nelson, Maya Lau
item.description: Accounts from employees at California postal facilities provide a glimpse of the chaos amid both the pandemic and widespread cuts imposed by the USPS.
item.content:encoded: Accounts from employees at California postal facilities provide a glimpse of the chaos amid both the pandemic and widespread cuts imposed by the USPS.

media:content.media:description: Postal workers sort parcels at Margaret L. Sellers Processing and Distribution Center at the USPS Carmel Mountain Post Office on May 14, 2020 in San Diego, California. The post office is seeing a huge increase in the amount of packages its handling.
media:content.media:credit: Eduardo Contreras/Eduardo Contreras/The San Diego Union-Tribune

item.description: With 233 positive tests among inmates â 226 in roughly the past two weeks â Folsom has the largest coronavirus outbreak in the state's prison system.
item.content:encoded: With 233 positive tests among inmates â 226 in roughly the past two weeks â Folsom has the largest coronavirus outbreak in the state's prison system.

media:content.media:description: California's prison system has regained control over inmate healthcare at Folsom State Prison. The state's remaining 33 prisons continue to be controlled by a court-appointed federal overseer.

media:content.media:description: VACAVILLE, CA - AUGUST 19: Firefighters battle fires along Lyon road during the Hennessy Fire on Wednesday, Aug. 19, 2020 in Vacaville, CA. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Bay Area has the world's worst air quality thanks to this week's Northern California fires
item.dc:creator: Joseph Serna, Susanne Rust, Rong-Gong Lin II, Maura Dolan
item.description: San Francisco Bay Area air quality is hazardous. Much of the ground is covered in ash distributed by gusty winds, adding to pollution already clouding the vicinity.
item.content:encoded: San Francisco Bay Area air quality is hazardous. Much of the ground is covered in ash distributed by gusty winds, adding to pollution already clouding the vicinity.

media:content.media:description: The San Francisco skyline is obscured by smoke from wildfires, as the Golden Gate Bridge rises in the foreground Wednesday, Aug. 19, 2020, in this view from the Marin Headlands near Sausalito, Calif. Crews were battling wildfires in the San Francisco Bay Area and thousands of people were under orders to evacuate Wednesday as hundreds of wildfires blazed across the state amid a blistering heat wave now in its second week. (AP Photo/Eric Risberg)

item.title: Education is a top U.S. priority, and there's wide support for online learning, poll finds
item.dc:creator: Nina Agrawal
item.description: A majority of respondents said they opposed reopening K-12 schools for in-person instruction in fall 2020 amid the pandemic.
item.content:encoded: A majority of respondents said they opposed reopening K-12 schools for in-person instruction in fall 2020 amid the pandemic.

media:content.media:description: WALNUT PARK, CA - AUGUST 13: Academia Moderna in Walnut Park, will reopen with a staggered schedule and smaller class sizes with increased distancing. Photographed at Academia Moderna on Thursday, Aug. 13, 2020 in Walnut Park, CA. (Myung J. Chun / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: 'Catastrophe' or 'new era'? Mail shake-up at L.A. public housing complex alarms residents
item.dc:creator: Emily Alpert Reyes
item.description: Mail would no longer be delivered to residents' doors at Mar Vista Gardens under a new plan. Officials say it would keep letter carriers safer, but residents are skeptical.
item.content:encoded: Mail would no longer be delivered to residents' doors at Mar Vista Gardens under a new plan. Officials say it would keep letter carriers safer, but residents are skeptical.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - AUGUST 18: Daisy Vega, president of the resident advisory council at the Mar Vista Gardens public housing complex, poses for a portrait in front of her apartment in Mar Vista Gardens on Tuesday, Aug. 18, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. She is worried about a possible change in mail delivery that would stop bringing letters to residents' doors, instead bringing them to centralized banks of mailboxes in the complex. (Dania Maxwell / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Bay Area firestorms send thousands fleeing and cause dangerous air quality
item.dc:creator: Susanne Rust, Anita Chabria, Rong-Gong Lin II, Joseph Serna
item.description: Many San Francisco Bay Area residents say they've never seen such wildfire conditions, a product of high temperatures, strong winds and thousands of lightning strikes.
item.content:encoded: Many San Francisco Bay Area residents say they've never seen such wildfire conditions, a product of high temperatures, strong winds and thousands of lightning strikes.

media:content.media:description: Matt Nichols sprays water while trying to save his home as the LNU Lightning Complex fires tear through Vacaville, Calif., on Wednesday, Aug. 19, 2020. Fire crews across the region scrambled to contain dozens of wildfires sparked by lightning strikes as a statewide heat wave continues. (AP Photo/Noah Berger)

item.title: Computer glitches, pleas for patience, worried parents and giddy kids mark back to school
item.dc:creator: Paloma Esquivel, Howard Blume, Andrew J. Campa, Cindy Carcamo
item.description: LAUSD students head back to school this week and the first days offer a look at the challenges ahead: computer glitches, worried parents and anxious students and teachers.
item.content:encoded: LAUSD students head back to school this week and the first days offer a look at the challenges ahead: computer glitches, worried parents and anxious students and teachers.

media:content.media:description: NORTHRIDGE, CA - AUGUST 18: Oliver Wendell Holmes Middle School principal Kim D'Aloisio hosts for a virtual meeting with staff socially distanced in the school auditorium to mark the beginning of the school year Tuesday, Aug. 18, 2020 in Northridge, CA. Brian van der Brug / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: At least 5 dead, nearly 700,000 acres burned as massive fires threaten Northern and Central California

Fire crews across the region scrambled to contain dozens of wildfires sparked by lightning strikes. (AP Photo/Noah Berger)

item.title: Skelton: Don't pay any attention to Trump. Voting by mail in California is safe, secure and reliable

item.description: "Voters should be able to cast their ballots in the safest way possible," Democratic Secretary of State Alex Padilla said. "The safest bet is to vote by mail."
item.content:encoded: "Voters should be able to cast their ballots in the safest way possible," Democratic Secretary of State Alex Padilla said. "The safest bet is to vote by mail."

ÂÂ B58838709Z.1 NORWALK, CA NOVEMBER 4, 2010: Nancy Fulton, a clerk, sorts vote by mail ballots in preparation for Friday's vote tally at the Los Angeles County Registrar's office in Norwalk. The race for California Attorney General will come down to a tally of vote by mail votes as Kamala Harris leads Steve Cooley by a slim margin. ( Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times )

Mayor Eric Garcetti at a reunion for injured firefighters at the Grossman Burn Center in West Hills Wednesday. The firefighters were caught in a ball of fire after an explosion at a buisness in Downtown Los Angeles in May. (Wally Skalij/Los Angeles Times)

item.content:encoded: Gov. Gavin Newsom said Wednesday he plans to apply to the federal government for a $300 weekly supplemental unemployment benefit for jobless Californians.

media:content.media:description: A job seeker waits to use a phone at a career center in Richmond, Calif. Economist Jack Kyser predicts that the state's jobless rate will average 12.6% next year, but other economists call his prediction overly pessimistic.

item.title: Firefighting helicopter crash kills pilot, sparks 50-acre fire in Fresno County
item.dc:creator: Joseph Serna
item.description: A firefighting helicopter crashed in Fresno County on Wednesday, killing the pilot and briefly sparking another brush fire to join the dozens burning across the state.
item.content:encoded: A firefighting helicopter crashed in Fresno County on Wednesday, killing the pilot and briefly sparking another brush fire to join the dozens burning across the state.

item.title: L.A. County finally seeing declines in Latino, Black coronavirus mortality rates
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby

item.content:encoded: Health officials note an overall drop in death rates across all demographics and a "narrowing of the gap" among coronavirus victims of varying racial, ethnic and socioeconomic backgrounds.

media:content.media:description: HOLLYWOOD, CA - AUGUST 18, 2020 - - Nurse Richelle Legaspi, a member of the outreach team with The Center, finishes giving John Yu, who is homeless, a COVID-19 test while outreach worker Douglas Walker, left, looks on in East Hollywood on August 18,, 2020. Members of the outreach team with The Center have been helping the homeless who have been dealing with the coronavirus pandemic and deliver food and water during the heat wave. The Center is a non-profit organization that has been helping the homeless community in Hollywood for many years. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: D.A. reviewing possible charges in Megan Thee Stallion shooting case
item.dc:creator: Richard Winton
item.description: The L.A. County district attorney's office asks the LAPD to further investigate an incident in which rapper Megan Thee Stallion claims she was shot.
item.content:encoded: The L.A. County district attorney's office asks the LAPD to further investigate an incident in which rapper Megan Thee Stallion claims she was shot.

media:content.media:description: FILE - In this Aug. 26, 2019 file photo, Megan Thee Stallion arrives at the MTV Video Music Awards in Newark, N.J.. The rapper says she was shot multiple times, but expects to fully recover. The 25-year-old said in an Instagram post Wednesday that she had gunshot wounds from a crime committed against her Sunday with the intent to harm her and feels lucky to be alive. She did not say who shot her or why, and Los Angeles police had no immediate comment. (Photo by Charles Sykes/Invision/AP, File)

item.title: California firefighting resources 'stretched' by 23 major wildfires, Newsom says

item.content:encoded: California is struggling to battle 23 major wildfires in what has become an acute fire season in the state.

Fire crews across the region scrambled to contain dozens of blazes sparked by lightning strikes as a statewide heat wave continues. (AP Photo/Noah Berger)

item.title: Destructive Bay Area fires fueled by rare mix of intense dry lightning and extreme heat
item.dc:creator: Joseph Serna, Rong-Gong Lin II, Leila Miller
item.description: Destructive Bay Area fires have been fueled by an unusual combination of dry lightning and extreme heat.
item.content:encoded: Destructive Bay Area fires have been fueled by an unusual combination of dry lightning and extreme heat.

media:content.media:description: A rare lightning storm crackles over Mitchell's Cove in Santa Cruz, California around 3 a.m. Sunday morning August 16, 2020. The severe storm system rolled through the San Francisco and Monterey Bay areas early Sunday, packing a combination of dry lightning and high winds that triggered wildfires throughout the region. The National Weather Service on Sunday extended a red flag fire warning for the entire Bay Area until 11 a.m. Monday morning. (Shmuel Thaler/The Santa Cruz Sentinel via AP)

item.title: Have you noticed any problems with the U.S. Postal Service in your area?
item.dc:creator: Laura J. Nelson, Maya Lau
item.description: Have you noticed any issues with mail delivery or with the postal service in your area? How have these issues affected you? Share your experiences with The Times.
item.content:encoded: Have you noticed any issues with mail delivery or with the postal service in your area? How have these issues affected you? Share your experiences with The Times.

media:content.media:description: Mail delivery vehicles are parked outside a post office in Boys Town, Neb., Tuesday, Aug. 18, 2020. The Postmaster general announced Tuesday he is halting some operational changes to mail delivery that critics warned were causing widespread delays and could disrupt voting in the November election. Postmaster General Louis DeJoy said he would "suspend" his initiatives until after the election "to avoid even the appearance of impact on election mail." (AP Photo/Nati Harnik)

Moore has been living homeless for the past two years. Members of the outreach team with The Center have been helping the homeless who have been dealing with the coronavirus pandemic and deliver food and water during the heat wave. The Center is a non-profit organization that has been helping the homeless community in Hollywood for many years. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

Officials hope to get the center open by 3 pm today, with cots set up 6 feet apart in separate areas for men and women. (Brian van der Brug / Los Angeles Times)

In the throes of the Covid-19 epidemic Continental Funeral Home struggles to keep up with the demands of rising death rates in a community suffering with health and finances. (Robert Gauthier / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Reopening elementary schools is risky â but so is keeping them closed
item.dc:creator: Rong-Gong Lin II

item.content:encoded: Experts say it's going to be a tough call for figuring out how to get elementary schools reopened. Reopening elementary schools when disease transmission is too high is risky.

(Josie Norris / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Cold-blooded or reformed? Clemency for a killer reopens a family's wounds
item.dc:creator: Kristi Sturgill
item.description: Forty years after a man was sentenced to life in prison for murdering his wife, he's been given a chance at freedom. The woman's family is shocked.
item.content:encoded: Forty years after a man was sentenced to life in prison for murdering his wife, he's been given a chance at freedom. The woman's family is shocked.

media:content.media:description: GLENDALE, CA -JULY 23, 2020: Debbie Bailey's family members from left to right-her brother-in law-Dave Goldsworhy, her sister and Dave's wife, Kathy Goldsworthy, her niece and Dave and Kathy's daughter Patricia Goldsworthy-Bishop, and her brother Jeff Bailey visit her gravesite, right, and her parents gravesite, Pauline and Robert Bailey, center, at Forest Lawn Memorial Park in Glendale. Debbie was cold-bloodedly murdered in 1980 by her husband Thomas Waterbury who has been in prison since. He was recently commuted by Gov. Gavin Newsom, though the family was not notified of his commutation or allowed to comment on the case (as they should have been.) (Mel Melcon / Los Angeles Times)

item.description: The LNU Lightning Complex fire has burned more than 124,000 acres in Napa, Sonoma, Solano, Yolo and Lake counties. Evacuations have been ordered in western Vacaville.
item.content:encoded: The LNU Lightning Complex fire has burned more than 124,000 acres in Napa, Sonoma, Solano, Yolo and Lake counties. Evacuations have been ordered in western Vacaville.

Fire crews across the region scrambled to contain dozens of wildfires sparked by lightning strikes. (AP Photo/Noah Berger)

item.title: Op-Ed: Warren Buffett can save the Klamath River Basin. Will he?
item.dc:creator: Jacques Leslie
item.description: The removal of four dams along the California-Oregon border is crucial to the Yurok and Karuk tribes, the Klamath's salmon runs and the river itself.
item.content:encoded: The removal of four dams along the California-Oregon border is crucial to the Yurok and Karuk tribes, the Klamath's salmon runs and the river itself.

media:content.media:description: FILE - In this Aug. 21, 2009 file photo, water trickles over Copco 1 Dam on the Klamath River outside Hornbrook, Calif. The process to relicense the hydroelectric dam system on the Klamath River has restarted again as historic settlement agreements to remove four of the dams have thus far failed to make headway in Congress this year. The Klamath River basin, which straddles Oregon and California, has long been the site of intense political fights over the sharing of scarce water between farms and fish. The agreements to remove the dams, hammered out by farmers, tribes, environmentalists and states, are a compromise aimed to restore the river for imperiled salmon and steelhead, and give farmers greater certainty about irrigation water. (AP Photo/Jeff Barnard, File)

item.content:encoded: Changes wrought by the COVID-19 pandemic have upended the lives of millions of dementia patients and their caregivers, who rely on long-standing routines.

media:content.media:description: Daisy Conant hasn't been diagnosed with dementia, but she has a family history of Alzheimer's and exhibits clear signs of memory loss. She gets frustrated reading news about the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: California to join legal challenge against Trump administration over USPS reductions
item.dc:creator: Maya Lau
item.description: The move comes as the postmaster general backs off changes for now. California's attorney general calls the changes an attack on a fair election.
item.content:encoded: The move comes as the postmaster general backs off changes for now. California's attorney general calls the changes an attack on a fair election.

media:content.media:description: FILE - In this Dec. 4, 2019, file photo, California Attorney General Xavier Becerra talk during a news conference in Sacramento, Calif. Attorneys general in 20 states and the District of Columbia sued the Trump administration on Tuesday, July 21, 2020, alleging that new federal rules undermine their ability to protect rivers, lakes and streams within their borders. "The Trump administration wants to clear the deck for fossil fuel infrastructure," Becerra alleged in announcing the legal action, the latest of dozens he has filed against the administration. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli,File)

media:content.media:description: Grace MontaÃ±ez Davis served as deputy mayor for Tom Bradley from 1975 until 1990.

item.title: For second day in a row, rolling blackouts across California are averted
item.dc:creator: Leila Miller, Alex Wigglesworth, Sammy Roth
item.description: State officials are continuing to urge conservation in an effort to reduce the need for power outages as the state's heat wave peaks.
item.content:encoded: State officials are continuing to urge conservation in an effort to reduce the need for power outages as the state's heat wave peaks.

media:content.media:description: From left, Sebastian Grand, 11, Leo Grand, 13, and Constantin Condraschi, 12, of Orange County laugh outside A Slice of New York Pizza in Seal Beach. The trio has been friends since preschool and had pizza after a day together at the beach.

item.title: Does L.A. count its homeless, or make its best guess? A little of both, it turns out
item.dc:creator: Doug Smith
item.description: Keeping track of the number of people who are homeless in Los Angeles is an exercise in uncertainty. Not only do the numbers change from year to year, presumably reflecting real shifts in the homeless population, but, once published, they can still change months or years later â based on changes in how the numbers are calculated.
item.content:encoded: Keeping track of the number of people who are homeless in Los Angeles is an exercise in uncertainty. Not only do the numbers change from year to year, presumably reflecting real shifts in the homeless population, but, once published, they can still change months or years later â based on changes in how the numbers are calculated.

media:content.media:description: NORTH HOLLYWOOD, CA - JANUARY 21, 2020 - Gospel musician Clemmie Williams, 34, lives homeless in North Hollywood Park on January 21, 2020. Williams has been working on part time jobs but it's not enough to make first and last for an apartment he says. "It's a struggle to get back to normalcy," Williams said. Williams was photographed on the first night of the 2020 LA County homeless count. On Tuesday, volunteers with the focused on the San Gabriel and San Fernando valleys. Other swaths of the region, such as the South Bay and Antelope Valley, will be covered Wednesday and Thursday.. The homeless count is overseen by the Los Angeles Homeless Services Authority (LAHSA) The volunteers will canvas more than 80 cities and 200 communities across L.A. County over three days to count the number of homeless people living on the streets, according to the LAHSA. Last year's count found that nearly 59,000 people were experiencing homelessness countywide, an increase of 12% from 2018. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Victims of Golden State Killer finally confront him in court with stories of pain and survival
item.dc:creator: Paige St. John, Luke Money
item.description: Victims of Joseph James DeAngelo Jr. will spend three days telling the court about the impact of his crimes before he is sentenced Friday.
item.content:encoded: Victims of Joseph James DeAngelo Jr. will spend three days telling the court about the impact of his crimes before he is sentenced Friday.

media:content.media:description: The victims of Joseph James DeAngelo Jr., the former police officer whose violent crimes through the 1970s and 1980s terrorized Californians across the state and earned him the moniker Golden State Killer, finally get their say in court beginning Tuesday, August 18, 2020.

item.title: L.A. County issues strict rules for colleges reopening during coronavirus crisis
item.dc:creator: Teresa Watanabe, Nina Agrawal
item.description: After months of waiting, L.A. County colleges received public health rules for fall reopenings: virtually no in-person classes and very limited on-campus housing.
item.content:encoded: After months of waiting, L.A. County colleges received public health rules for fall reopenings: virtually no in-person classes and very limited on-campus housing.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - AUGUST 17, 2020 - - USC student Mitchell Steimle, 21, from left, and his brother Anthony, 18, participate in a wellness check conducted by Campus Health and Screening Ambassadors Sonya Melendez-Fitzgerald, 54, and Ethan Perreira, 21, right, on the first day of academic instruction at USC for the Fall 2020 semester in Los Angeles on August 17, 2020. All students who visit the campus have to go through a wellness check, answer questions regarding COVID-19 symptoms and have their temperature checked before they are allowed to enter campus. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: From 'firenadoes' to record heat, California extreme weather a glimpse of future
item.dc:creator: Tony Barboza, Louis Sahagun, Joseph Serna
item.description: As one of the worst heat waves in years continues to broil California, millions are experiencing the havoc that ensues with the type of extreme weather that is growing more frequent with climate change.
item.content:encoded: As one of the worst heat waves in years continues to broil California, millions are experiencing the havoc that ensues with the type of extreme weather that is growing more frequent with climate change.

media:content.media:description: Lightning forks over the San Francisco-Oakland Bay Bridge as a storm passes over Oakland, Calif., Sunday, Aug. 16, 2020. Numerous lightning strikes early Sunday sparked brush fires throughout the region. (AP Photo/Noah Berger)

item.title: 'Are we ready?' LAUSD's first day back to school, online and on Zoom, is anything but normal
item.dc:creator: Howard Blume, Paloma Esquivel, Andrew J. Campa
item.description: The L.A. Unified School District opens online Tuesday. But the typical excitement is tempered by families' anxiety and confusion as educators try to offer a 'normal' school day that is anything but amid the coronavirus.
item.content:encoded: The L.A. Unified School District opens online Tuesday. But the typical excitement is tempered by families' anxiety and confusion as educators try to offer a 'normal' school day that is anything but amid the coronavirus.

media:content.media:description: WALNUT PARK, CA - AUGUST 13: Xavier Reyes, founder of Alta Public Schools, shows the reduced size and increased spacing in classrooms at Academia Moderna in Walnut Park. The school will reopen with a staggered schedule and smaller class sizes. Photographed at Academia Moderna on Thursday, Aug. 13, 2020 in Walnut Park, CA. (Myung J. Chun / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Police reform advocates scrutinize police unions, calling them obstacles to reform
item.dc:creator: Kevin Rector
item.description: Police reform advocates who for years have searched for roadblocks to accountability have zeroed in on a new target: police unions.
item.content:encoded: Police reform advocates who for years have searched for roadblocks to accountability have zeroed in on a new target: police unions.

media:content.media:description: FILE Ã¢ÂÂ In this March 26, 2016, file photo, Black Lives Matter activist DeRay Mckesson, chatting with campaign volunteers in Baltimore. A federal lawsuit accuses Black Lives Matter and several movement leaders of inciting violence that led to a gunman's deadly ambush of law enforcement officers in Baton Rouge last summer. Mckesson and four other Black Lives Matter leaders are named as defendants in the suit filed Friday on behalf of one of the officers wounded in the July 17 attack by a black military veteran, who killed three other officers before he was shot dead. (AP Photo/Patrick Semansky, File)

item.title: Overruling Cal State trustees, Newsom approves new ethnic studies requirement
item.dc:creator: Nina Agrawal
item.description: Gov. Gavin Newsom signed legislation that makes ethnic studies a graduation requirement across the California State University's 23 campuses.
item.content:encoded: Gov. Gavin Newsom signed legislation that makes ethnic studies a graduation requirement across the California State University's 23 campuses.

media:content.media:description: A banner hangs from an upper-floor railing as students demonstrate at Cal State L.A. in support of the ethnic studies programs.

item.title: Firefighters combat several dozen fires in Butte County
item.dc:creator: Leila Miller
item.description: Firefighters battled several dozen fires Monday in Butte County.
item.content:encoded: Firefighters battled several dozen fires Monday in Butte County.

media:content.media:description: Oroville CHP units are closely monitoring the fire in the Potters Ravine area.

item.title: As California clears backlog of COVID-19 cases, deaths hit a low for the month
item.dc:creator: Laura J. Nelson
item.description: Gov. Gavin Newsom said San Diego County, the state's second largest, could be taken off the watchlist this week.
item.content:encoded: Gov. Gavin Newsom said San Diego County, the state's second largest, could be taken off the watchlist this week.

media:content.media:description: SYLMAR, CA - AUGUST 17: Ian Roistacher and his brother Mitch Roistacher, 4, walk back to their hotel room after picking up back-to-school supplies for Ian's three younger brothers during a fair at the Vagabond Inn in Sylmar on Monday, Aug. 17, 2020. The event, on the first day of school, was a partnership between Councilwoman Monica Rodriguez and L.A. Family Housing providing students with backpacks full of school supplies and other essential items for the family. The families participating are those facing economic hardship because of the pandemic. (Myung J. Chun / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California's top court caps penalties on nursing homes to $500 for certain lawsuits
item.dc:creator: Maura Dolan
item.description: Ruling on a 1982 law, the California Supreme Court has limited damages against nursing homes to $500 per lawsuit, a victory for the industry amid the coronavirus crisis.
item.content:encoded: Ruling on a 1982 law, the California Supreme Court has limited damages against nursing homes to $500 per lawsuit, a victory for the industry amid the coronavirus crisis.

media:content.media:description: California Supreme Court Justice Mariano-Florentino CuÃ©llar, seen in January, wrote the 4-3 ruling that said a government agency's legal bills are generally public record in cases that have been resolved.
media:content.media:credit: Brian van der Brug / Los Angeles Times

item.title: California's first plague case in 5 years is confirmed in South Lake Tahoe
item.description: El Dorado County officials said Monday that the California Department of Public Health notified them of the positive test of a resident who is under medical care while recovering at home.
item.content:encoded: El Dorado County officials said Monday that the California Department of Public Health notified them of the positive test of a resident who is under medical care while recovering at home.

media:content.media:description: KINGS BEACH, CA -- MAY 07: The north shore of Lake Tahoe on Thursday, May 7, 2020, in Kings Beach, CA. Cities and counties that live off tourism are strategizing for how to prepare for an influx in out-of-towners when coronavirus restrictions are lifted. (Gary Coronado / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Flex alerts: Ways to conserve power and stay cool
item.dc:creator: Jessica Roy
item.description: Here are some ideas for reducing power usage and cooling down while California's flex alert is in effect.
item.content:encoded: Here are some ideas for reducing power usage and cooling down while California's flex alert is in effect.

media:content.media:description: The thermometer at Calvary Church in Woodland Hills registers 106 degree's Monday.
